intro: Blepharis diversispina var. furcata, commonly known as the forked bluemouth, is a perennial herb native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, erect stems and small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its flowers, which range in color from white to pink, bloom in summer, attracting various pollinators. The species is noted for its unique branching pattern, with the stems often splitting into two or more branches near the base.
